prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: J1041-1156
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: A clustered field of LBGs at z=5.1-5.20, Independent pointings on 8 spectroscopically confirmed targets, incorporating 6 additional photometric z~5 LBGs.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We estimate our signal to noise based on rebinning to a single 100 km/s channel. This would be (just about) possible with the continuum setting of the correlator. However, we expect the actual velocity widths to vary over a range which could span from 30 km/s up to 300 km/s. As a result, we choose a higher spectral resolution setting in order to measure the line profile of well-detected sources, while allowing us to adopt spectral averaging in data reduction to recover broad, low signal to noise sources. Ideally we would choose slightly higher angular resolution than 3 km/s - however, given the redshift distributions in these clustered fields (typically delta(z)~0.1) and the likely (small) offset between Lyman alpha and CO redshifts, due to asymmetric absorption and scattering of the Lyman-alpha line, we require a broad baseline to ensure the line emission is not missed, as well as optimising the cluster volume probed for blind line detections. Therefore we adopt the broadest correlator configuration possible at sub 100 km/s line resolution and use the 3.12 km/s correlator setting.
This setting is used in the two subbands which probe the redshift space of the Lyman break galaxy cluster. We adopt a lower resolution,continuum setting in the remaining subbands in order to provide the best possible continuum constraint (although we do not expect to detect continuum at these frequencies), while remaining open to the possibility of blind detections.

We expect our sources to be point sources. HST imaging has suggested that the typical angular size of these galaxies in the ultraviolet is 0.15 arcseconds (half light radius), with a subset of sources comprising multiple components seperated by ~1 arcsecond, and a few more extended. We estimate a likely largest angular scale of about 0.5 arcsec (the size of the most extended object in our uv-imaging) and we ask for comparable angular resolution in order to distinguish emission from multiple components where present, and to avoid any issue of ambiguity when identifying the optical-IR counterpart of detected emission (these faint galaxies typically have a neighbouring lower redshift object within a few arcseconds projected distance).

There is very little observational constraint on the infrared luminosity or CO line strength of the majority of these targets. Coppin et al (2015) found L_FIR ~ (1.1 +- 0.5) x 10^12 Lsun for a stacked sample of z=4.8 LBGs, but these were selected for SCUBA-2 follow up as bright in the (observed) near-infrared, biasing the sample relative to those observed here. Davies et al (2013) stacked sources in the E-CDFS, obtaining a non-detection limit of L_FIR < 5 x 10^11 Lsun for z>4 sources. Assuming these sources follow a comparable CO-FIR relation to known galaxies (Solomon and vanden Bout 2005), this upper limit yields L'_CO < 5 x 10^9 K km/s pc^2(2 sigma on the stack, with considerable scatter on the conversion). This is consistent with our own non-detection limit from previous investigations on a stacked subset of the current targets (Stanway et al 2008, Davies et al 2012). Capak et al (2015) observed a small sample of z~5.5 LBG targets from the COSMOS survey, finding that most had L_FIR < 3 x 10^10 Lsun, with a few individual detections at around this level. Although the cosmic time between z~5.0 and z~5.5 is short, the evolution in the population appears to be rapid, complicating the interpretation of this constraint. Our targets are typically brighter than the COSMOS sample, and at somewhat lower redshift.
Here we target the CO J=5-4 transition of CO. In part this choice is constrained by ALMA's bands - this is the lowest angular momentum transition we can probe with ALMA. However the effects of temperature and physical conditions of the gas are seen most strongly in the higher order rotational lines of CO. LBGs at z~5 have incredibly high surface densities of star formation and ultraviolet radiation intensity (see Lehnert et al 2015) which are likely traced by high surface densities of dense gas rather than the diffuse gas (traced by e.g. [CII] emission). Rotational emission in CO does not require the gas to be photoionized, but the lower energy lines can be suppressed in a high intensity environment. With measurements in the J=5-4 transition, we potentially probe close to the peak in emission, regardless of whether the gas is photon- or shock-excited, providing a good constraint on the temperature and density of the gas, particularly when combined with our existing constraints on the lower order lines (accessible in the radio).
Band 3 is also well suited to these observations; in addition to targetting the lowest-excitation lines accessible to ALMA, it has a comparatively large primary beam and so allows a large fraction of the cluster volume to be probed in a limited number of pointings.
We set a target depth per target of L'_CO ~ 5 x 10^9 K km/s pc^2. In converting from a CO(1-0) line estimate to one in the CO(5-4) transition, we assume the gas is thermalised yielding a predicted peak line flux of 2.94 mJy. We request a 10 sigma detection on this line peak. We recognise that the line may be sub-thermally excited. The star formation density in these systems is high, similar to that in ULIRGs. However the star formation rate is relatively low (<10 Msun/yr). Assuming an intermediate excitation ladder between ULIRG and Milky Way-like states, we would still expect a 5 sigma detection. Clearly, our 3 sigma non-detection constraint will be lower still, and this can be improved by a factor of ~4 by stacking our targets with known spectroscopic redshifts.
Our target depth is not constrained by the proposed blind line detection in this field, we note that, assuming sub-thermal excitation reducing the CO(5-4)/CO(2-1) line ratio by a factor of 2 from thermalised, we would expect to recover this source at 20 sigma if the initial interpretation was correct.
Again, we have little constraint on the line velocity widths. Estimates from optical lines, [CII] lines (e.g. Capak et al 2015 who found sigma=63-163 km/s) and modeling suggest ~100 km/s as an appropriate line width (FWHM) for star forming galaxies in this mass range.

The high data rate arises from the low resolution settings used in two sidebands. These are necessary to span the redshift range of the cluster at sufficient resolution to measure the line widths of strong sources (which may be sub 100 km/s in width). There is not an available correlator setting that provides the broad wavelength coverage while allowing our optimal (20 km/s) resolution.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: J1054-1245
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: A clustered field of LBGs at z=4.95

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We estimate our signal to noise based on rebinning to a single 100 km/s channel. This would be (just about) possible with the continuum setting of the correlator. However, we expect the actual velocity widths to vary over a range which could span from 30 km/s up to 300 km/s. However the star formation rate is relatively low (<10 Msun/yr). Again, we have little constraint on the line velocity widths. Estimates from optical lines, [CII] lines (e.g. Capak et al 2015 who found sigma=63-163 km/s) and modeling suggest ~100 km/s as an appropriate line width (FWHM) for star forming galaxies in this mass range, and we use this for our estimates. These are necessary to span the redshift range of the cluster at sufficient resolution to measure the line widths of strong sources (which may be sub 100 km/s in width). There is not an available correlator setting that provides the broad wavelength coverage while allowing our optimal (20 km/s) resolution.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: J1054-1245 Group 2
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: A clustered field of LBGs at z=4.95

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Lyman break galaxies (LBGs) are the most commonly identified candidate sources at high redshift (z>5). However, LBG selection identifies objects on a high current ongoing star formation rate, with little sensitivity to the galaxy's eventual mass, reservoir of molecular gas or future star formation; a wide range of gas masses can be expected. However, when the selected LBGs are destined to form massive galaxies in current-day massive groups and clusters, it is clear that significant gas reservoirs must exist either in their close environments to account for the future star formation necessary to form these massive systems. Consequently searches for cold gas associated with LBGs may be significantly more successful in clustered and proto-cluster fields. Here we propose band 3 imaging of 18 pointings in two fields previously identified as hosting overdensities of spectroscopically-confirmed Lyman break galaxies at z=5. We will measure the CO(5-4) emission line, probing the gas mass of these system and the diversity in the population. In combination with existing multiwavelength data we will constrain the star formation efficiency and gas depletion timescales of cluster LBGs.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe
